prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
This is an exploratory proposal to detect sub-mm H2O megamasers in AGNs. The masers are expected to arise within a pc of the central black hole and will be unresolved by ALMA. We do not know how strong the 321 GHz masers will be in our three target galaxies, but we can use the 22 GHz lines as a rough guide. In the Circinus Galaxy, Hagiwara et al. (2013) detected the 321 GHz line with a peak flux density of 131 mJy/bm, and an integrated flux density over all components of 14 Jy km/s. The 22 GHz lines in Circinus have an integrated flux density of ~60 Jy km/s (Braatz et al. 1996), and highly variable peak fluxes near ~ 10 Jy. Meanwhile, in evolved stars the 321 GHz masers are generally comparable in flux to their 22 GHz counterparts. So as a guideline we might expect 321 GHz megamasers to be a few times weaker than the 22 GHz lines.
In our three targets the brightest 22 GHz components peak at ~ 400 mJy and high-velocity components peak at ~ 100 mJy. We request an rms sensitivity of 3 mJy per 2 km/s channel in order to detect features as faint as 15 mJy at 5 sigma.
Maximizing velocity coverage is critical to our science, since one of our aims is to detect gas closer to the black hole than the 22 GHz lines. With a ground energy of 1846 K, 321 GHz masers may be excited at high temperatures in the accretion disk corresponding to rotation velocities up to a few times larger than those traced by 22 GHz lines. So we have placed two spectral windows in the sideband to cover nearly the full bandwidth available, with contiguous coverage. We also require high spectral resolution (~ 1 km/s) to detect narrow maser lines, which are ~ 2 km/s in width. Our configuration gives ~ 3300 km/s velocity coverage.

This is an exploratory proposal to detect sub-mm H2O megamamasers in AGNs. The masers are expected to arise within a pc of the central black hole and will be unresolved by ALMA. Extragalactic megamasers at 658 GHz have not yet been detected, and we do not know the fluxes of the 658 GHz lines in our three target galaxies. Stellar masers at 658 GHz generally have flux densities several times larger than their 22 GHz counterparts, and in a few cases they are orders of magnitude stronger (Menten & Young 1995). If the same is true for megamasers, we should be able to detect these masers with relatively short integrations times (< 1 hour). We have set our sensitivity requirement at 15 mJy per 2 km/s channel.
Maximizing velocity coverage is critical to our science, since one of our aims is to detect gas closer to the black hole than the 22 GHz lines. We have placed four spectral windows in the sideband to cover nearly the full sideband, contiguously. We also require high spectral resolution to detect narrow maser lines, which are ~ 2 km/s in width, so we are using the 1875 MHz FDM-mode for each window. Our configuration gives ~ 3200 km/s velocity coverage.
The data rate for our Band 9 observations is 22 MB/s. The correlator configuration we are using is essential to our science, since we seek to detect narrow maser lines at unknown rotation velocities that could reach +/- 1500 km/s from the recession velocity of the galaxy.

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract: Water-vapor megamasers at 22 GHz provide the only means for directly mapping gas in AGNs on sub-pc scales. In about 20% of megamasers, the emission originates in thin, edge-on accretion disks within a parsec of the central black hole and traces Keplerian rotation within the black hole sphere of influence. These disk masers yield "gold standard" masses of the supermassive black holes plus, in a few cases, angular-size distances to the host galaxies and a direct measurement of the Hubble constant. AGNs are expected to produce water masers at sub-mm wavelengths as well, but they are largely unexplored. For the first time, ALMA provides the sensitivity needed to study extragalactic sub-mm water masers. We propose to observe 321 GHz, 325 GHz, and 658 GHz water masers toward 3 galaxies with 22 GHz Keplerian maser disks. These sub-mm maser species can sample gas at different temperatures and densities than the 22 GHz lines, and they might trace the accretion disk much closer to the black hole than the 22 GHz lines. If they are bright, the sub-mm lines may greatly increase the power of megamasers to measure black hole masses, distances, and physical conditions in accretion disks.
